reviewText: This game is imaginitive and reaches into your hearts and brings out the true adventurer. Although you are always the size of a munchkin, you get to delve deep into the mysteries that are the catacombs, caves, and dungeons that lay within ruin below civilization. You and your awesome transformable pet try to regain your power and fame, you against the world for the cause of a hero is with you. But seriously, I love the game, even though it's a slow start at a low level(you can cheat), once you get past a certain level you are met with real challenges(unless you cheated), and the game actually takes concentration and strategy. And once you finish the game, you can choose one object and it becomes a relic for your ancestor, who you playthrough 2 as! Replay value is immense, none of the quests are ever the same, nor the items, and you make a cool lineage of hero's! Kinda sounds like Fable to me, but none-the-less I give this game a rating of 8/10. Losing points for originality and lack of major plot.

reviewText:
I never imagined I'd be posting a negative review for any of the FATE games ...

Not only was FATE a blast to play in its day.  But it should be of special interest to anybody who happens to be a fan of both Diablo II and Torchlight.  FATE is like the missing link that came between those two games.

Sadly, the only reason for my thumbs-down here is to help purchasors beware it's become impossible for most users to play any of the FATE games anymore under Windows 10.

So I'd just hold onto your wallets for now:  Don't  assume that since your other games are still running smoothly after you upgraded to Windows 10 that any of the FATE series will.  It won't!

FATE unfortunately just has critical compatibility issues now with Windows 10; can't get any further than the first menu or so for most users without a crash to desktop no matter what tips they try.

It's a shame to lose being able to play such a classic as FATE.   So I'm still hoping for a Steam/Wildtangent fix.  But until then, I'd just continue to watch this space.

reviewText:
tl;dr:Play Torchlight 1/2 over this if you can.

Actual Review:Fate is a Hack & Slash in the same vein as Diablo 2,Titan Quest and Torchlight(this franchise began waaay before Torchlight and actually inspired a lot of mechanics for Torchlight.)
It's fairly simple to pick up,you make a character,pick gender,choose from a limited set of appearances and load up in the game.
It's exactly like the first Fate,all the systems and mechanics of the previous game are present in this installment,and while it adds some new things,like more unique items and items in general,more pet transformations and two outposts to chose from over the generic setting of Grove in the first game..i can't recommend this game,and i think that a big part of that is because i played Torchlight 2 before i played Fate.
Fate introduced a lot of cool systems that weren't done(as far as i know,don't take this for granted) such as the pet system and the ability to tell your pet to go to town and sell all your items you don't need(so handy!!),more freedom when it comes to class specialization,fishing for pet transformations and such things like that.
And thats kinda where my positives about the game end,since i played TL2 before Fate,it felt to me like i played a inferior version of Torchlight,everything that Fate does now is done muuuuch better in Torchlight 2,i personally found the music of Fate pretty good but became very old very quickly since the game has a very limited soundtrack,i disliked the art-style and the generic and basic feel of the combat. The story is a pretty boring one aswell,the narrator is abit wooden if you ask me,i quickly just ignored the story and focused on the game's mechanics instead.
When it comes to a very important part of an Hack & Slash,Fate just fails to entertain me with good and unique items,it's your typical 4% extra damage and +15 fire damage,nothing interesting,the game also has no active skills aside from magic,no melee or ranged skills that you can activate,no talents or very indepth specialization like you have in Diablo 2,all you do is increase Strength and put 2 points in Spear skill when you level up and that was fine in 2005 but in 2015 it's been done so much that quite frankly,i'm sick of it.
The combat is also pretty straightfoward,just hit the enemy with your sword,walk back as the enemy begins attacking then hit the enemy again,and because of the fact that the combat isn't very satisfying,it's tedious.And this becomes even more apparent in the abhorrent Hardcore mode which increases enemy damage and health to an unfair level while giving you nothing,and it locks to permadeath(which i'd be fine with if it weren't for the artifical and BS difficulty)

But,i have to stress that my experience is somewhat spoiled because of the fact i played Torchlight 2 before i played Fate,so if you never played TL2 or any Hack and Slash,Fate is actually a very good and basic choice to get into the genre,it's straightfoward and decent at what it does,it does have a helpful amount of tips in the loading menus,there are no complex systems like the charge system in Torchlight and there isn't a very big amount of strategy required to be good at the game.
So while i appreciate and respect what Fate meant for the Hack and Slash genre,and while it brings a loooot of good and sensible mechanics into the genre like pets and such,Torchlight 2 just does it so much better that i can't recommend it in this day and age.
And that's a shame because Fate is a pretty significant game when you see what it inspired and i had a decent time with,it just doesn't hold up against TL2 in any way shape or form.
voteText: 12 of 26 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This sequel of FATE is wraught with bad design choices. As a new character you're bound to get frustrated by dungeon levels giving enemies 10 levels extra, while you're lucky for 1-2. Even combining the 2 dungeons the game is rich, that means max 4 levels per 10 level increment.
It is not unlikely to get a starter-quest at dungeon level 2, being level 2 where you have to defeat a lvl 8 alter (not that bad right) defended by 3 lvl 14's who can 3-shot you. Good thing there are 3. If through massive potion use and much much cheesing you defeat one, it will just be respawned by the altar... great fun! (NOT)
And this just one example of many more.

It seems intended for characters who finished FATE, but what fun would be going lvl 10 again with your powered up FATE character. Not to mention between the game balance gets completely lost since  a lvl-up in 1 means 4 skillpoints, in 2 it's only 2. Just to screw over new characters even more?

What is the result of all this abonimable game design you ask? A terrible unfun game. If you seek to quench your thirst for hack&slash, play the original FATE or one of the Torchlights instead. Avoid this game like the plague...

reviewText:
This game is a weaker version of Torchlight II, Diablo 3 and Van Helsing. This game feels like it was unfinished and chucked out at the last moment due to budget constraints. You can see many similarities to Torchlight such as the animal companion. Enter the dungeon, go down the levels, collect quests that specify which level the random boss is on, kill boss, collect loot and turn in quest. Rinse and repeat. It's that simple. It's lame.

PROS
1. Simple to learn
It's like any other isometric RPG.

2. Summon Spells
The timber wolves and beetles looked good. They were also pretty interesting.

CONS
1. 1 Spell at a Time
That's right. Spells are divided into Attack, Defense and Charm types and you can only use 1 at any moment. You can switch spells but it's really dumb.

2. Lousy Graphics
It's really bad.

3. Dead NPCs
They just stand there like lamp posts fulfilling roles like a vending machine.

4. Lame Storyline
Book of Fate? That's it?

5. Permanently Deletable Spells
CTRL click to lose a spell permanently. You have a limited number of slots to learn spells in.

6. Obnoxious Amounts of Gold To Learn Spells
If you don't have the gems to sell, you're pretty much unable to buy spells

7. Only 2 Major Zones
Typhon, the ice land and the other one, Druantia.
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Hope you like rolling boulders up hills grinding with monotonous combat mechanics, because that's what the FATE games are all about.  Maybe they weren't that bad for their time, but there's no reason to play them anymore (assuming there ever was).  They get old quickly, and there's hardly anything to distinguish them from each other (they're so similar, I have no problem just copying and pasting the same review on each of the three that I own).  Moreover, there's nothing to distinguish them from the more recent Torchlight (not surprising, given that the Runic Games team includes ex-WildTangent devs), except Torchlight is better in every respect: better graphics, better combat, and better performance (despite being developed for Pentium systems, the FATE games still manage to overheat my Core 2 Duo gaming laptop even while running at 800x640 with minimal graphics quality).  Want to play a dungeon crawler?  Play Torchlight.  Already played Torchlight?  You're still probably better off replaying it, or playing its sequel (disclaimer: I have not).  If you really insist on getting a FATE game, I suggest starting with Cursed King, since it at least adds a little more character customization and a much-needed button to quickly swap weapon loadouts.

reviewText:
Idiots made this game!

WHY?

Because it is much harder than it really needs to be.

BECAUSE:

You enter a dungeon, Have a partial fight
If your really lucky you may even kill what ever it is you fighting.
If not really lucky, you DIE!!!

RESULT (of just one fight, regardless of outcome):

Return to a city to get healed. Sure you get a few HP potions, but once these are gone (which will not take long), it's back to town you go! You will spend more time traveling between town and your desired destination than you really should!

VERDICT:

You will eventually be able to grind your way to a suitable level to fight the beginner crap, but do you really want to play nothing but grind.

SUGESTION (for improved game play):

Allow player to rest, recovering HP


ps: After coming back to this game and forgetting how to actually attack, this game sucks!

reviewText:
Unofficial Torchlight Predecessor [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]

This is the first standalone expansion (the others are The Traitor Soul and The Cursed King) for the game Fate, released in 2005. This is a diablo-like action RPG with all the frills: random generated levels, lot of quests, different weapons, spells and so on.

While the gameplay is pretty solid, there are some problems: music is below average, levels are re-generated if you leave them, you are overwhelmed with junky items, inventory management is quite messy, it gets repetitive, experience points can't be reused forcing you to never change the skill path you choose at the beginning of the game.

I recommend buying Torchlight instead: it is the unofficial FATE 2 (the game director left the FATE team to build it): more polished, less buggy, better gameplay, more fun. :-)

Best played with Keyboard and Mouse
Recommended Buy Price < 5$
Score 7/10

reviewText:
I was a late bloomer to playing the Fate series.  At the point that I discovered it, I had already played Torchlight and that is the best way to summarize my feelings of this game.

FATE was the precursor to Torchlight.  Even down to the very concept of fishing for items and to change the characteristics of your journeying sidekick pet.  The game is fun.  Torchlight did well to follow (and expand upon) the guidlines the FATE series created.

If you want some good ol' nostalgia dungeon-crawly goodness, you'll enjoy the game.  Despite playing and beating BOTH Torchlight games, I still find FATE very enjoyable.

reviewText: A great game in a great series. I think this game deserves a lot more attention. It is very low-spec, so It is one of the only games that still runs perfectly on my old computer. The soundtrack is epic and catchy, as I randomly find myself humming some of the tunes from this game. Of all the games in this series, this is my favorite because you are not just stuck in one world - you can travel to other realms. This game is also great for coders or novice coders, as modding is really easy in this game. A lot of people may hate on the game due to the old graphics, but I dont care much for looks. This game is definitely one of my most favorite games of all time, I give it a great 9/10.

reviewText: Playing the hard level.  My favorite weapon is the bow  and it seems this and all other fate games forget about the bow.  They are few and far between and when you do find one either the level or the attribute requirements are so high they are unusable.    Do I recommend this game?  It depends on how you want to play.  It is typical of other Fate games with changes to monsters, etc.  But the game itself is very similar.

reviewText: I am the second person in the reviews to find out that clicking on a shrine for a protect shrine quest crashes the game back to desktop and you restart the dungeon level from the beginning every time. I'd like to point out I was enjoying the game up until that point. That bug should be fixed and then I could recommend it.\n\nEdit: This has since been fixed and as I said, I now recommend it. Good game!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I have bought it as part of Humble Bundle package. I would say that nothing was changed from previous game (FATE), so you can buy either of them and enjoy it. It is more like a DLC adding 3 new dungeons (with infinite number of levels underground) the separate game although THIS IS separate game.

I enjoy it, although I find it really strange that game force you to complete 2 dungeons and then allows you to play third but sets the difficulty again to the level of complete novice although it is impossible to play it without getting your character and arms upgraded during previous 2 dungeons. It gets too easy to play this levels and there is not much fun in that :-(.

For anyone already having previous game, boy it if you can buy it dirty cheap, otherwise stick with FATE.
For someone not owning FATE, pick either FATE or FATE: Undiscovered realms as they are kind of same game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: My family loves all the FATE games. I am now waiting for a Windows 10 fix so I can play them. I have always had problems with Wild Tangent games. I used to buy them from a store and install them, only to be told I have to purchase coins to play them. I would contact Wild Tangent and they would fix it, but it would sometimes happen again. I was happy to see Fate games on Steam and purchased a couple of them. We were happy once again until I downloaded Windows 10. I was never told these Fate games wouldn't work with Windows 10, and they haven't fixed this issue yet. Thanks, Wild Tangent (or Windows). I think I will protest by not purchasing any more Steam games until this issue is fixed. To Steam: Don't sell PC games that don't work on a PC.

reviewText: This game gives me a nostalgia-boner! I used to play the first FATE. One of the cool things is: You start, buy a fishing rod. You then start fishing, after while you get a hat made of cheese.... Next thing you know... you have so much money to spend that you are OverPowered. The strength of this game is that is a hell of a lot of fun even when you are OP.\n\nThis game has almost infinite replayability, because you can build a character any way you want.... You want a spell casting Tank? Sure! Why not?

reviewText: Kept running into visual bugs in Fate (lighting all blacked or whited out) in certain dungeon rooms.  Not sure if this is just my comp/settings or what, but by the third time it happened it just made me want to go play Torchlight.  VERY similar mechanics.  Like, there is no one was inspired by the other" to it:  this is straight up the same system (pets
hoursPlayed: etc.) with a different UI skin.\n\nI played Torchlight first and I liked it better
voteText: because it was just a little more polished in a lot of categories:  better graphics
votesTotal: etc.  It all translated to "slightly more fun".  Combined with the bugs
votesFunny: Fate just wasn't enough to keep my interest when there are very similar games that do the same thing better."

reviewText: This is an old childhood game of mine. I have always loved it and still do! Who wouldn't want to transform their pet into a giant spider, a gryphon or a venomous wyvern? Or summon venomous wyverns of your own? Mystical swords floating around you guarding you? Casting a meteor spell upon your enemies? Equipping a giant scythe or crossbow, games like these have so many wonderful options.\n\nI wish there was a remake of this game. It looked so different and fun when I was a child. Now as an adult it's mere nostalgia, but I can still enjoy the game, just not as much as I did years ago. The Torchlight series (at least II) feels different in a lot of ways, too different for comfort. That's why I'd prefer a remake.

reviewText:
Under Windows 10 this is a ridiculous, buggy disaster.

It took some doing to get the game to run at all, though there's information in the Discussions that can help you. Essentially, the game doesn't create its own (long, complex) configuration file, so you have to do it manually or the game will crash before it even gets started.

Once in game things seem to work basically correctly. Gameplay is similar to Diablo or Torchlight (very much like Torchlight, complete with the feed your pet fish to change it" mechanic). You're in an isometric-view dungeon
date: various NPCs give you quests to destroy this or kill that
recommended: and you go do it. Disconcertingly
hoursPlayed: your character appears to be about 10 years old
voteText: and there's no character class -- all you choose at the start is name
votesTotal: and whether you have a dog or a cat. There's enough randomness that the difficulty curve is questionable
votesFunny: but it's a serviceable game of its type.\n\nJust ... don't try to run it in fullscreen
commentsCount: don't try to open the minimap ... and there's apparently a host of other gamebreaking bugs that I didn't personally encounter listed in the Discussions.\n\nIt's unlikely the publisher is ever going to come back and fix this mess with a patch for Win10 compatibility
column16: so I'd recommend just sticking with Torchlight. It's essentially the same game with better graphics."
